The government is being forced to make a Commons statement on David Cameron's plan that all energy companies be required to give their customers the lowest tariff.

Labour is convinced that Cameron, speaking in the Commons on Wednesday, tripped up and went further than a policy being prepared by the Department of Energy and Climate Change (Decc).

The Commons Speaker, John Bercow, has granted the shadow energy secretary, Caroline Flint, an urgent question on the plans, which Labour said were "unravelling by the minute".

A spokesman for Decc said the energy minister John Hayes would answer the question. Energy Secretary, Ed Davey, was giving a speech on energy market reform in the City on Thursday morning.

Labour sources claimed that Downing Street, instead of admitting Cameron had inadvertently gone further than intended, tried to defend the policy, but has now come under intense pressure from energy companies and civil servants to revise the plan.

Ed Miliband, an energy secretary in the last Labour government, had previously proposed that energy companies be required to provide the lowest rate, but only for those aged over 75. It was notable that no one from the energy companies or an energy minister appeared on major news programmes on Thursday as Whitehall went into overdrive to try to sort out the policy.

The prime minister has been warned he will kill off competition in the energy market if companies are forced to give all their customers the lowest tariff available.

Cameron said: "We have encouraged people to switch, which is one of the best ways to get energy bills down. I can announce that we will be legislating so that energy companies have to give the lowest tariff to their customers – something that Labour did not do in 13 years, even though the leader of the Labour party could have done it because he had the job."

The unequivocal pledge by the PM on the forthcoming energy bill caused some surprise in Decc. One source said: "We are looking at lots of ideas about how to use the law to get the lowest tariffs. We are exploring all the options."

One price comparison website warned that legislation could work against consumers' interests by killing competition. Ann Robinson of uSwitch.com, said: "This has to be a mistake – the unintended consequences would be to kill competition. Consumers will be left with Hobson's choice – there will be no spur, no choice, no innovation and no reason for consumers to engage any more. The only glimmer of hope would be that smaller suppliers will be able to offer cheaper prices than the big six and therefore competition is able to continue in that arena."

Cameron made his announcement in response to mounting concerns over rising household energy bills – four of the UK's big six energy firms have already announced above-inflation winter price hikes.

After the announcement, a spokesman for the PM said: "We've asked energy companies to take action themselves and make clear what the lowest available deals are. The point is, in practice this market is not operating for everyone. A small minority of people are actually switching deals, therefore we need to push some of this responsibility on to the energy companies."

He said customers would have to wait until the bill was published, possibly in the autumn, for details of how the change would work in practice. The move did not mean energy companies would offer only one tariff, as different customers would need different rates. "At the moment, the way the market works, people are encouraged to switch but many people don't … so lots of people are not benefiting from that market, particularly vulnerable people who are less likely to switch deals."

Citizens Advice is launching the Big Energy Saving Week on 22 October to target millions of families across the UK with advice on keeping energy bills down.

The campaign coincides with a warning from the price comparison site energyhelpline.com that the best fixed rate energy deals – including deals from Ovo Energy and First Utility – were "disappearing fast".

The government will outline plans on Thursday for a new £160m gas market infrastructure. It will "remove an ambiguity" in the Gas Act to make it easier for Ofgem to launch an innovation competition that could attract £160m of extra investment. The Electricity Act will also be amended so developers will only need to undertake a three-month consultation if they want to change plans to incorporate the most energy-efficient measures.

In the final announcement Davey will say that reforms in the energy bill will unlock £110bn of new investment in the electricity market.

Every summer, jobbing academics experience the same shock. After months of marking word-processed essays, you are confronted with exam scripts and you see the thing itself: handwriting – reams of it. Whatever the varying qualities of all the different students' different essays over the year, print has invested them with a semblance of uniformity. Now you can really see the sheer variety of hands and, it would seem, personalities. The pile of handwritten essays is a kind of visual cacophony – spiky or looped or crabbed or wandering, with every shade of blue or black, every kind of pressure and slant and flourish. They could not look more different from each other.

Philip Hensher's celebration of handwriting and the individuality it enacts comes at a time when, because of technology, this once essential human activity seems "about to vanish from our lives altogether". Everything is typed or texted. The apparent demise of handwriting is nothing much to do with educational ideology. Hensher notes that the National Curriculum makes rather stern demands of a child's handwriting skills, describing the seven levels through which a young person must pass to get from the basic shapes and orientation of letters to a script that is not only legible but "attractive". Yet to some (including a few of his more benighted creative writing students, it would seem) handwriting is simply unnecessary.

Reading this book reminds you of the aura that a specimen of handwriting can have – all the more so as it becomes a rarer thing. Literary manuscripts perhaps most vividly preserve the heat of a person's singularity. Keats's letters are wonderful to read in print, but look at an actual letter in a photograph or a museum's glass case and you see something more. "This living hand, now warm and capable" reaches towards you. From Alexander Pope's disconcertingly perfect and pretty script to Byron's slapdash rapidity to Sylvia Plath's wobbly yet decisive jottings, struggling to find invisible lines and margins, handwriting seems to show us how an extraordinary person felt as well as what he or she wrote.

As handwriting matters very much to those who study literary authors, so its significance recurs in many literary works. Some of the best chapters here are the self-contained studies of particular writers. There is a brilliant little piece on how handwriting features in Dickens's novels, where so often "the act of writing, of forming letters, acts as an impetus for the plot". Most will remember Lady Dedlock in Bleak House suddenly glimpsing a sample of her dead lover's handwriting, but Hensher gathers many more examples. You realise that Dickens had a thing about it.

Another chapter fixes on Proust's odd predilection for illegibility in the letters of some of his friends, turned to revealing account when we see how illegible handwriting features in the plot of A la recherche du temps perdu. Legibility being potentially "shallow and cruel", the impenetrability of a person's script becomes a metaphor for their complexity. Proust's narrator is, we are made to see, excited by the mysterious signs of individuality he detects and tries to describe in a person's handwriting.

What for the novelist is a fascinating hypothesis became a pseudo-scientific creed in the work of graphologists. In the late 19th century, there was "an explosion in books explaining how to discern character from handwriting". Sherlock Holmes's certainty in The Sign of Four that he could divine a suspect's character from the way he formed his letters ("There is vacillation in his k's and self-esteem in his capitals") was a habit of his times. What started as a Victorian parlour game became a weirdly respected science. It is shocking to discover that, in the late 20th century, leading European and American companies might still have been using graphology in making their recruitment decisions.

Hensher thinks that the idea of handwriting as distinctive of an individual came only in the 19th century, and he specifies court cases in which this was first enshrined in law. Yet this cannot quite be right. The 18th-century novelist Fanny Burney sedulously disguised her handwriting in the 1770s to prevent being outed as the author of Evelina, while in the 1720s Jonathan Swift had a friend write out the copy of Gulliver's Travels supplied to his publisher so that his authorship would not be recognised.

Here, as sometimes elsewhere, the historical generalisation comes a little too easily. And, disappointingly, Hensher does not go back very far. There is a spirited rumination on the qualities of Elizabeth I's signature, but otherwise nothing much on handwriting before the 18th century. The book does not reach back to the English manuscript culture that keeps palaeographers in business – the alien conventions of the "secretary hand" beloved of Elizabethans, the beautiful strangeness of the hands used by medieval scribes.

He really gets going in the 18th century with the development of copperplate, "still the hand we reach for at elevated moments of our lives" (you see it replicated in printed form on certain kinds of invitation, especially to weddings). Oddly, it is preserved in the official logo of Coca-Cola. Then there was italic, developing from the faux antiquity of William Morris and hardening into the instructive books of Monica Bridges. It is a style that Hensher himself enjoys using, but one whose zealous proponents, influential in English public schools, he disdains. Quoting several stalwarts of the Italic Handwriting Society, he characteristically exclaims: "What came first – being an arse, or writing in italics?" One of the paradoxes of the story he tells is that, while handwriting is an expression of individuality, self-appointed experts have always strived to regularise it.

The history explains how different nations have different handwriting habits as a result of past projects of regimentation. The Germans have only fairly recently extricated themselves from enslavement (for such it seems) to the Fraktur script that approximates to black-letter prints. Americans distantly owe their preferences to AN Palmer, whose Guide to Business Writing established the connection between his method for forming letters and commercial success. The heroine of Hensher's story is Marion Richardson, proponent of child-centred learning, whose 1935 manual Writing and Writing Patterns formalised her advocacy of children's delight in scribbles and patterns. In her educational practice Hensher finds a pleasure in idiosyncrasy that he shares.

This pleasure licenses his own digressive and colloquial style (a footnote that begins "This is nothing to do with anything …" gives you the tone of voice). The anti-solemn footnote is his speciality. He quotes a Scottish headmaster who doubts the importance of training in handwriting and his footnote performs a tizzy of exasperation. "Oh, crap. Seriously, what crap … Jesus, sometimes you really want to give up". Some digressions, such as his capsule history of ballpoint pens, serve a good purpose; others, such as a long account of trying to buy a fountain pen with an italic nib at various leading West End stores, do not. The historical descriptions and case studies are interleaved with space-filling transcripts of chats he has had with relatives and friends. They may show that individuals do think and care about handwriting, but they contain not a single observation that has stayed with me.

The book ends with an anecdote about his experience of finding a notebook filled with the jottings of someone who had recently died. It is a telling example of how the very flow and contour of handwriting gives back something of the person who produced it. Many readers will know what it is to come upon the handwriting of someone they once cared for who is now dead, and to feel the shock of proximity. As much as any photograph, and more than any sound or video recording, handwriting can bring back to us the essential character of a person.

"Writing this book, I've come to the conclusion that handwriting is good for us. It involves us in a relationship with the written word which is sensuous, immediate, and individual. It opens our personality out to the world." You have to agree. As a history, The Missing Ink is patchy and too anecdotal for its own good, but its advocacy of one of the most humane and pleasurable forms of self-expression is pretty much irresistible.

Colin Cram, consultant specialising in public sector procurement and a former director of the North West Centre of Excellence

Procurement is a prisoner to how the public sector is organised, ie, its organisation is internally facing. It needs to be organised in a way that enables it to deal most effectively with the private sector. In areas where it is essential to get it right for quality as well as price, such as NHS drugs procurement, there is a central team doing it on behalf of the whole devolved NHS structure. The same principles should apply to other procurements. The procurements may be diverse, but for major projects many of the skills required are the same.

Service level agreements would ensure that internal public sector customers got what they wanted. Fortunately for it, public sector procurement has no external competitors. The status quo is, therefore, preferable for those who work in it. As things stand, there will never be enough specialist expertise to go round the several thousand public sector procurement organisations. Therefore, things will go obviously wrong. Who would know if one is paying far too much for a contract? Staff reductions of up to 30% can still result in a much better procurement service? Who would want that? Certainly not many procurement people.

The EU procurement directives are used as an excuse, but they have not caused problems in securing value for money through best practice, such as working up and down supply chains to take out unnecessary cost and risk. It is worth noting that, without the EU directives, Virgin is unlikely to have had a successful appeal. The directives have forced improved procurement standards in many parts of the UK public sector. The more capable and savvy procurement directors have used them effectively as an argument to get increased staff resources and investment in systems and training.

Coherent might be a better word than centralisation. We need a coherent organisation that is based on central, regional local structure, ensuring markets and suppliers are properly managed and specialist and commodity expertise is available to all. It would also provide procurement people with a great career structure and probably a much better structure for training them. Imagine the depth of outsourcing expertise that such an organisation could possess. Many suppliers find the lack of experience and specialist expertise in the organisations with which they are dealing to be extremely frustrating and costly. Others simply take advantage of it.

Stephanie Elsy, managing director of a business delivering efficiency in public services. Previously senior director of Serco Group

Social value depends on the determination of the commissioner to get it from the provider: they must include social outcomes in the selection criteria. If it is not explict, it won't happen because the bidders will not cost it in. This can be done and is being done. One of my favourite examples is the original contract that TfL had with Serco for the Docklands Light Railway - there were explicit requirements around local community engagement and employment practises.

Government procurement is done under appalling public scrutiny; the private sector does not have to cope with this and can, unless it is of a fatal magnitude, hide its mistakes. There needs to be a centralised, mandatory procurement function, but I think it should be under Treasury or Cabinet Office control, not separate from government. This is what most large businesses do – and it works for the most part.

The media picture of the Department for Transport could be an incomplete, distorted picture. All I would say is that people make mistakes and, for a disaster to happen, it usually takes quite a few people to make mistakes or not do what they are supposed to do. As my history teacher used to say, the one thing we learn from history is that people never learn from history. Pay may be an issue in retaining experienced people, but I suspect other factors, such as lack of resources, organisational turmoil with cuts and poor systems, could also have played a part – but this is speculation.

Paul Kennedy, chief executive of CEL Group, which provides procurement and business services to public bodies

Data and technology have a huge role to play in the areas of commoditised procurement. The standardisation and availability of the data, to support meaningful analysis remain the problem. A recent report on behalf of the Government in the Republic of Ireland showed that, out of a total spend of €9bn (£7.3bn) on goods and services, €6.9bn was classed as "addressable by procurement". Some €4.3bn was thought to be addressable centrally, €2.1bn to be sector specific and, interestingly €0.5bn remained unclassified because of the poor quality of data.

Su Maddock, senior fellow at the Manchester Institute for Innovation Research

Procurement is being used as a panacea for achieving often conflicting objectives. For instance, the Department for Work and Pensions expected work programme procurement to deliver service innovation, efficiency savings and to transfer risk from the taxpayer to the private sector all through a neat two-tier model. Now even prime contractors are challenging the assumptions made and say they cannot afford the development costs of social innovation. There is a need for much more openness about commissioners (political) expectations and analysis of whether the business and procurement models adopted can deliver expectations.

Procurement officials are constrained by broader frameworks. All small organisations find public processes difficult. If commissioners prioritise "transferring risk" that cuts out even medium-sized companies. It seems to me that adding on social values clauses is not going to overcome these structural problems. Within the civil service and the wider public sector there has grown up a set of assumptions around what business models lead to efficiencies and that these not challenged enough – all models having a gearing, and it is frequently towards rationalisation rather than supporting the relationships that are shown to support holistic services. Rather than searching for the most effective national procurement services, I think locality commissioners are more likely to procure from who have a track record in inter-agency.

Richard Branson did us a favour by challenging the Department for Transport. Whatever you think of Virgin, he did reveal to the public that government procurement decisions are quite often based on delusional claims to win contracts. I think it is a problem in a democracy that policies are fought over but that transactional processes are assumed to be neutral, when they're not.

Adrian Quayle, managing director of P&Q Consulting, and a board member of the National Outsourcing Association

Time is crucial. Those that work well have properly considered what they are trying to achieve, such as outcomes and benefits. They haven't just jumped straight into procurement on a cost and risk basis. The existence of this strategy and feasibility stage is essential and needn't take long but is often omitted in the rush to get into evaluation and contractual discussions. It's absence then impedes the process as much of the thinking, then has to be "retro-fitted" into the selection and contractual process. This is even more difficult to do in formal OJEU-based public procurement.

The British Standard on Collaborative Business Relationships is gaining traction. The challenges of large and complex collaborative relationships were among the triggers for its development. The two parts of the standard set out good industry practices across the whole of the lifecycle (including procurement). The standard is beginning to get significant traction in a wide range of organisations across the private and public sectors – more than 25 have now certified against it.

Mentoring is necessary. In the private sector over recent years, much work has been carried out in establishing highly professional supplier relationship management (SRM) functions and teams. The skills they have increasingly focused on have been the softer aspects of culture and behaviours as part of broader performance management. The involvement of these teams in the procurement process is now recognised as essential. A significant number of these SRMs have been through the university accredited National Outsourcing Association pathway programme. An extension of this into the public sector will provide capabilities and the alumni are already acting as a very effective support structure. We've also seen significant development in coaching and developing through the rise of mentoring organisations operating in this area.

Nigel Clifford, chief executive of the e-commerce network Procserve

The challenge is sometimes making the intangible tangible. I was lucky enough to be in the NHS for six years (I mean that). It was the most complex but satisfying buying and supplying environment I have worked in – needing very deep thought on priorities and justifications that can be defended against a price-cost benchmark. A happy ward environment or a good patient experience needed a strong multifunctional buying team to define what lay beneath the outcome and how to communicate it quantitatively.

Sharing best practice is essential, both through sharing personnel as on secondment, using Charted Institute of Purchasing and Supply tools and resources and using the contracts and systems that are available. However, it is important that this is inclusive and builds the talent pool rather than alienating the public servants who are the constant in the procurement function. We need champions to whom ambitious twentysomethings can aspire to be in the future. Is procurement sexy enough and seen as a great and meaningful career? Personally I think it is and should be.

Tim Heywood, specialist public procurement and commercial lawyer

The Government Procurement Service and civil servants handling commercial contracting are not well-supported. They handle what are often highly complex, high-profile matters and they have to do it with very modest resourcing. Their specialism is not fully recognised or valued in Whitehall, although this is improving, but those who do choose to specialise in procurement in the civil service are generally very capable and industrious.

There is a short term resourcing and capabilities issue about how to increase the overall levels of commercial awareness, negotiating skills and nous in the civil service. Training and development are certainly part of the solution. But they will deliver medium and longer term solutions. A collaborative approach which brings in the best of the public and private sector procurement and contracting capability is needed to address the short-term challenge.

The decision-making issue is a vital one but commercial nous can't be taught: I worked in Whitehall for 15 years or so. Much of that time was spent on commercial matters. This is a good thing obviously, but it cannot be a substitute for a number of skills and abilities. Commercial nous is probably one of them. I'm not sure it can be taught: you've either got it or you haven't. Negotiation, too, requires the individual to have certain personal characteristics. It is not something you can do by rote. So some of this capability (people who already have these skills) needs to be identified and deployed more effectively so that they can add the value that's needed. If it can't be identified and deployed from internal resources quickly enough, it will need to be bought in.

Andy Moran, director of Plan Procure Manage

External consultants find it easier to challenge service delivery managers in a way that procurement departments would not. I think a lot of this is to do with the service-delivery-led structure of most councils. Traditionally, procurement has been a reactive support service within maybe the finance department and not had a seat at the top table.

Changing expectations for public sector procurement is at the root, the whole reason for this debate. What is it we expect public sector procurement people to do and, actually, is there more than one type of procurement person. The technical procurement knowledge is really a very small part of the story for a public sector procurement person. It's becoming more and more about business analysis, project management and political awareness.

Narrow thinking must be dispensed with. A few years ago I did some work with a local authority to renegotiate care home contracts and introduce payments linked to quality standards. What struck me most of all was that, when I went out to visit the homes and meet the suppliers, that for all of them it was the first time they had met anyone from the council procurement and commissioning teams. Some of these care homes were being paid over £1m a year.

Gary Bandy, freelance consultant and a former local authority finance director

Local government procurement hierarchies need adjusting. I don't think I know of any local authority where a procurement specialist is at the top table. There has been a continuing debate for years in local government about whether the finance director should be a member of the top management team, and many authorities do not do it. Private companies that have a significant supply chain would likely have a board director responsible for it. As local authorities, and other public bodies, move further towards a commissioning model, is there a case for them to have a commercial director on their top team?

EU procurement objectives is a way to scrutinise public bodies and gives the public confidence. However, over recent years I've detected a growing unease among organisations about the potential for challenge from unsuccessful bidders (and others). I suppose the recent successful appeal by Virgin Trains will exacerbate this uneasiness.

If localism is to mean anything then public bodies should commission bespoke services. This is rather than have a centrally-procured service imposed on them. That's assuming a central unit could, for instance, commission a contract that could be easily implemented piecemeal across the country.

International cricket, albeit of the unofficial kind, is due to return to Pakistan this weekend, for the first time since the Sri Lanka team were attacked in their bus on the way to a Test in Lahore in March 2009. An International World XI team captained by Sanath Jayasuriya, managed by Alvin Kallicharan, and including a number of intrepid South Africans such as Andre Nel has been assembled to play a couple of Twenty20 matches against a Pakistan All Stars XI team at the National Stadium in Karachi on Saturday and Sunday.

The Pakistan Cricket Board has stressed that the games are unofficial, having left security arrangements in the hands of Mohammad Ali Shah, the sports minister of the Sind province, and the rest of his team who came up with the idea. But it has allowed such high-profile contracted players as Shahid Afridi and Younis Khan to take part in the fixtures, and clearly hope that if they go ahead successfully, it will be another major step towards convincing the cricketing world that playing in Pakistan does not constitute an unacceptable risk.

Staging the matches will be a triumph for Pakistan, and cricket, to celebrate, at a time when the country is still recovering from the shock of the shooting of Malala Yousafzai, the 14-year-old schoolgirl who is now in hospital in Birmingham after being shot in the Swat Valley by a Taliban gunman for daring to press the case for female education.

In that context, the development and success of the Pakistan women's team in recent years seems to be a more relevant cause for celebration. Less than two decades ago, the idea that women could play cricket to a high standard and even represent the country provoked angry protests, and was even forbidden by the government. Now, they have a full-time contracted squad, who are currently preparing to leave for the Asia Cup in China after making a hugely positive impression in the ICC World Twenty20 in Sri Lanka – where they claimed a thrilling victory against India by one run.

"This is the reality of modern Pakistan," said Ayesha Ashhar, the manager of the team, from her office in Lahore. "Since we won the Asian Games two years ago, which was a major breakthrough for women's cricket, but even before that, there has been no objection. People accept that women can play cricket, and they come to watch women playing cricket as they would men."

The Pakistan team have an eloquent ambassador in Sana Mir, the 26-year-old from Abbottabad who was one of the stars of a brunch to promote the women's game held in Colombo on the day of the World T20 finals. "It was a great moment for us that Sana was invited to speak at that function, and to represent the whole of women's cricket," added Ashhar. "I respect and admire her so much, not only for her cricketing ability, but also for the leadership qualities she shows."

Next week she will lead her girls to Guangzhou, of all places, for an intriguing eight-team tournament that involves Thailand, Hong Kong, Nepal and the hosts China, as well as the established quartet of Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and India – who will be set on revenge when they face Mir's team in the last round of group matches on 28 October.

Sri Lanka also claimed a completely unexpected win in the World T20 against West Indies who were widely fancied to challenge Australia in the semi finals – only for the Aussies to shock England in the final, an against-the-odds achievement that perhaps has not received suitable recognition in England given the gulf in the support given to the women's game in the two nations.

For all the warm words about the growing profile of women's cricket that have followed, with the England captain Charlotte Edwards and other members of her team touring the BBC for a round of pretty soft interviews, the performance department at the England and Wales Cricket Board will presumably be asking some tough questions about the team's failure to perform to their potential in that final. The pressure will now be high on them to deliver in the 50-over World Cup early next year in India – if women's cricket is to be taken as seriously as it deserves, that level of criticism and accountability must be accepted as part of the package. In Pakistan, the team's apparently widespread acceptance at home is a cause for greater celebration in itself.

The chief of the Taliban in Pakistan has ordered his followers to target media organisations critical of the group's attempt to murder 14-year-old Malala Yousafzai.

The scathing media coverage of the Taliban for the shooting, in Pakistan and elsewhere, is said to have enraged Hakeemullah Mehsud, head of Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP).

He has therefore issued directives to his subordinates in the Pakistani cities of Karachi, Lahore, Rawalpindi and Islamabad to target certain television channels and their editorial staff. And journalists in Swat have received threatening phone calls warning them of serious consequences for giving coverage to the Yousafzai case.

Intelligence agencies intercepted a phone conversation between Mehsud and a TTP operative in which he gave the directives to attack media organisations.

Yousafzai, who was flown to Britain on Monday, is said by doctors to have a good chance of making a recovery. She was shot because she advocated education for girls. But the TTP regard her as a "spy of the west".

She has become a potent symbol of resistance against the Taliban's efforts to deprive girls of an education. A TTP statement said: "We did not attack her for raising voice for education. We targeted her for opposing mujahideen and their war. Sharia says that even a child can be killed if he is propagating against Islam."

Is the economy really in as bad a state as certain sections of the media would have everyone believe? Not if the audience and some of the panellists at a recent small business panel in Leicester are right. Things are more difficult than they were five years ago, certainly, but despite bouts of what one panellist called "Pestonitis" in honour of the BBC correspondent, some businesses are reporting their best-ever year.

The main thrust of the initial debate, though, was about opening new markets. Chairing the event, the Guardian's industrial editor Dan Milmo introduced Philip Taylor, international business manager, Northants Beds Bucks & Herts, for Lloyds TSB. He said one of the biggest issues with exporting and creating new markets was that too many people ask for advice on exporting too late. "It's sadly too frequent that someone comes to me with a contract and says 'I've signed this, enlighten me a bit on the payment methods', and I have to say, 'you've already signed the contract, so you're tied into it'." Sources of advice such as UK Trade & Investment were also ignored by many small businesses until too late, he said.

Being flexible and ready to adjust to what is actually going on are also very important, according to Professor Simon Lilley, head of Leicester University's school of management. "We've been working with a local taxi firm that has been hit by the austerity measures," he explained. Cuts have meant that a lot of the customers, for a firm servicing social services and education clients, have reduced taxi use. "So the firm started examining cost bases and revenue streams, and began by looking at keeping the vehicles on the road longer and taking down maintenance costs.

"They've done that so phenomenally well that their business is now developing into 'we'll keep your car on the road', and they're running a taxi firm on the side," he said.

The lesson here was to look at where a business is uniquely placed to make an offering regardless of whether it's the same one as a year ago.

The flipside is that inflexible businesses might suffer, although Alice Barnard, chief executive of the Peter Jones Foundation, still found that attitudes in the media were impeding confidence – a theme that had been raised in other seminars.

"Negativity is the antithesis of everything an entrepreneur stands for," she said. "I'd be an advocate of banning phrases like 'since records began' … we know where we are, we know roughly how it came about, so let's stop talking about that and work out where we're going next."

One audience member suggested that the whole focus had to shift from increasing sales, whether through new markets or not, which is difficult at the moment, to making those sales more profitable. Panellist Ron Lynch, regional director of the IoD East Midlands, agreed. "A lot of businesses have re-costed things and as a result there is more profit around," he said. "The problem is they're not investing at the moment." There was a need both to generate more sales and to invest in growth, he added.

A lively exchange towards the end of the session involved one member of the audience suggesting that too many new entrepreneurs have missed the business basics but still have a sense of entitlement. "Banks have made mistakes, but I wouldn't lend someone money unless I could get some assurance on their plan and the finance behind it," he said. "You're talking basic stuff here."

He suggested there was a media-led impression that people had to get a university education in order to get a job, implicitly endorsed by successive governments, but his organisation had successfully taken on school leavers at 16. "You don't have to have a degree unless you want to be a solicitor or something, it's all getting too complicated," he said.

Barnard's colleagues in the audience defended the training on offer at least from the Peter Jones Foundation, which offered business planning, and the ability to present to and work with backers, among similar basics. The audience member felt this was good but that overall there was too much emphasis on getting overqualified without the required commonsense. "The world is not the kind of place the media has portrayed," he said. "Since 2009, yes, the world is tough but there's no use moaning about it, it's not as bad as has been made out."

A lot of business success was about staying in control, said Lynch. One of his contacts had been asked what it was like running her business, and she had said it was like pulling a cart, with all the customers, suppliers and staff on it. "Someone said to her, you've got it the wrong way around, you should be on the cart and the others pulling you," he said. "It took something like that for her to see the opportunities for her business." She subsequently appointed a non-executive chairman and chief executive to turn the company around.

Mostly, though, growth is about business acumen and sometimes being tough enough, the panel agreed. In previous times, it had been possible to ask the bank for a loan and get it easily enough. While it's not impossible now, anyone asking for money needs to have the mindset of a financial director, the ability to not only ask for money but to say precisely what they plan to do with it.

Lynch summed it up by recalling an analogy that had been explained to him a while ago. There are three sorts of business, first the lions, who are predatory, go out and find new markets. Then the mules, the reliable enough but uninspiring ones who form around 80% of the economy – and the turkeys, who need no explanation. The trick, he said, was to get some of the mules to think about being lions – and to get the lions some profile to inspire further mules.

I brake suddenly, faced with a large dark shape on the road. The beast runs off into the woods before I get a closer look but thanks to numerous travel reports of wild boar hogging the roads around East Sussex, its identity is obvious. When not causing traffic jams, they are a celebrated local delicacy.

Rye has an annual event devoted to them. Wild Boar week, starting on 27 October, sees exhibitions, quiz nights, parties and, happily, a plethora of restaurants serving the meat up in all shapes and sizes, as pressed belly, in black pudding, steaks, sausages, stews, cured as charcuterie and every other conceivable way.

"Genuine wild boar, as opposed to farmed, is a truly local product," says the festival's organiser, Oliver Campion. "This is one of very few parts of the country where a lot of wild boar roam the woods."

The animals were once common on the English landscape before being hunted to extinction during the 17th century. Around 15 years ago, according to the British Wild Boar organisation, they began to re-emerge in the woods and forests of Sussex. It's thought they must have escaped from farms, been dumped by illegal importers or set free by animal rights activists. However they got there, they began doing what animals do – breeding.

By the turn of the millennium, wild boar colonies were established in East Sussex, Kent, Gloucestershire and Devon. There are thought to be between 500 and 1,000 animals in the UK now although there are concerns that the population in some areas is under threat. Unlike other types of game there is no official boar-hunting season, no time when they are allowed to breed and wean their young with impunity. The British Association for Shooting and Conservation advises that firearms certificates should be authorised to shoot wild boar. Two dogs can be used to track animals, but they can't be hunted in packs.

"Four or five years ago the boar in this area were out of control," says Alistair Ball, a forester in East Sussex. "People began shooting them and now the numbers are dwindling." This concerns Sussex butcher, Jamie Wickens, who sells fresh wild boar meat from his premises in Winchelsea Beach. He wants Defra to create an official hunting season so the animal does not die out in the wild here a second time. "I sell genuine wild boar during the game season but with no law against it others may not be so scrupulous."

Brought up cooking wild boar in the Lombardy region in his native Italy (where numbers continue to thrive), Gabriele Pastellanza, chef at The George in Rye now serves it in a variety of forms. "It's a very versatile ingredient," he says. "Because the animal is wild it's more meaty and has a much richer flavour than farmed meat."

The authentic unfarmed meat has a distinctive texture and bears little resemblance to pork, looks more like steak, tastes like a cross between organic pork and venison; like other game, it's a great hearty, nourishing meat, best served on crisp autumnal days or cold winter nights.

Although it's possible to buy farmed wild boar elsewhere throughout the year, it is the rarity and superior flavour of authentic wild boar that makes it such a prized delicacy, from butchers and farmers' markets in the areas where the animals roam.

Our local travel news still regularly warns to avoid the beasts on the roads. I'd prefer to come across them at the local butcher or in one of the pubs and restaurants in UK wild boar territory.

Healthcare managers will be gathering for the Foundation Trust Network conference next week at a time of growing confusion as to how the health reforms are going to operate.

The health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, appears unwilling to read from the script that Andrew Lansley left him. There are strong indications in his first few weeks that he does not recognise the wall that is being erected between the politicians and the NHS under the new regime, and is repeatedly pushing into territory which Sir David Nicholson and the NHS Commissioning Board regard as theirs.

And, just as the new minister starts behaving like an official with operational control, Nicholson has been behaving like a politician. His recent comments to a conference of GPs were extraordinary. He said: "Big, high-profile, politically driven objectives and changes like this almost always end in misery and failure." He is right, of course, but it is all but unprecedented for someone of permanent secretary rank, in effect, to ridicule government policy in this way.

Is this how the new separation of powers in the NHS is going to work – ministers trying to interfere on the one hand and the commissioning board feeling it has the autonomy to attack government policy on the other? If the commissioning board is going to have a row with the government, money is the likely battleground. All parts of the provider system are feeling the pressure.

It is tempting to divide foundation trusts into two camps: those who are struggling and those who are thriving. It is certainly true that small district general hospitals and those with PFI deals tend to be the ones finding it hardest to adapt to the new financial climate, but even the big foundation trusts are finding it tough. All of them are plagued by uncertainty — about income, about the impact of commissioning changes, about reconfiguration.

The Nicholson challenge to achieve £20bn of efficiency savings is not going to be met. The King's Fund's quarterly monitoring report published in September said finance directors from a range of organisations were on track to achieve their planned cost improvements for this year, but many already see little chance of the overall target being hit.

Monitor's review of foundation trust plans for 2012-13 predicts savings will exceed 4% for each of the next two years, but that is not going to do the job. In this first 18 months of the challenge, trusts have been stripping out the easily identifiable inefficiencies and benefiting from the pay freeze. But the freeze cannot go on much longer and further savings will be much harder to deliver.

If there was to be any chance of saving £20bn the early progress would have needed to be much more dramatic. This will increase pressure for reconfiguration of services and sorting out uneconomic trusts.

There seems to be some appetite among foundation trusts for taking over struggling trusts, but the risks must weigh heavily on any hospital board. The slump in the performance of Heart of England foundation trust after it took over ailing Good Hope serves as a powerful warning of the likely consequences of trying to resuscitate a failing hospital.

Many foundation trusts are finding it tough enough to manage waiting lists and A&E access times without taking on someone else's problems. There are also nerves about local opposition. Foundation trusts considering a takeover struggle to align local opinion-formers – MPs, councillors and the media. That is a lot of pain for little obvious benefit to the foundation trust.

In the short term at least, foundation trusts are likely to suffer from the growing pains of clinical commissioning groups. Monitor expects groups will struggle to manage demand for their first year, and foundation trusts that try to meet demand substantially above the level they had planned for often see their profitability weakened. This shows the folly of launching a wholesale reorganisation in the middle of a financial crisis.

The difficulties faced by foundation trusts are extensive and deep. Too many are finding it too difficult to adapt to the new health economy. Substantial restructuring is inevitable.

Mitt Romney has latched onto Barack Obama's failure to follow through on a 2008 campaign promise of immigration reform in a new Spanish-language television advert aimed at trying to win over some of the largely pro-Democratic Latino vote.

The 30-second spot picks up on the president's difficulties over the issue from Tuesday's night's presidential debate and Obama's admission during an interview with Spanish-language Univision that the lack of immigration reform was his biggest failure.

"The liberal Democrats promised immigration reform," the advert says. "Now, the Democrats say they never made a promise."

Romney also hit Obama with the accusation of breaking a promise during Tuesday's debate.

"When the president ran for office, he said that he'd put in place, in his first year, a piece of legislation – he'd file a bill in his first year that would reform our – our immigration system, protect legal immigration, stop illegal immigration. He didn't do it. He had a Democrat House and Democrat Senate, super majority in both houses. Why did he fail to even promote legislation that would have provided an answer for those that want to come here legally and for those that are here illegally today?" Romney said.

Obama sidestepped the question, listing changes to the immigration system he had made but not addressing why he failed to put a bill to Congress for comprehensive reform.

However, while many Latino voters are unhappy with the president about that, there is little evidence they have confidence in Romney and the Republican party to address immigration in a way that is sympathetic to undocumented migrants.

Romney's advert promises to unite families, provide work permits and find permanent solutions for undocumented youth living in the US. But he has offered only sketchy policy proposals and Obama noted that Romney's adviser on the issue was at the forefront of drawing up Arizona's controversial law permitting the police to challenge people over their immigration status.

In a second Spanish-language advert released on Wednesday, Romney attacks Obama with allegations he has made more than $700m in cuts to Medicare – a theme the Republicans have repeatedly pressed during the campaign despite fact checkers saying the charge is false.

A palatial pumphouse, an immense stone spillway and a London roundabout are among the 10 most threatened Victorian and Edwardian structures in England and Wales, according to a list published on Wednesday.

The list, compiled by the Victorian Society, also includes an abandoned railway station in Derbyshire, an ivy-shrouded mortuary chapel in Salford and the country's first lending library, housed in Swindon's Mechanics Institute – all of which have fallen into a shocking state of disrepair.

The publication follows a widespread appeal to find the best and most at risk buildings in England and Wales, with historians, enthusiasts and local campaigners suggesting endangered structures in their area.

"The public responded enthusiastically to our call for threatened buildings," said Chris Costelloe, director of the Victorian Society. "It shows the public cares – but it also shows there are still too many historic buildings at risk, without recognition or protection."

Many of the buildings follow a similar story, of redundant public facilities falling into private hands, after which they have been left to deteriorate. Ipswich county hall, built as the town's jail and law court, once boasted fine wooden panelling and stained glass windows. Sold off and left to decline, it has now been stripped of its copper and lead, its windows smashed and interiors vandalised.

"It was designed to instil awe and civic pride," says Costelloe. "Now it only inspires pity and anger."

A similar fate befell the Swindon Mechanics Institute. Built in 1855 and paid for by rail workers, it began a network of healthcare facilities that inspired the National Health Service. Nye Bevan, mastermind of the NHS, said: "There was a complete health service in Swindon. All we had to do was expand it to the country."

But since its closure in 1986, the building has fallen prey to vandalism and arson. The Victorian Society insists that a workable plan must be provided by the council if the building is to survive.

Tumbling down a hillside in Marsden, West Yorkshire, the majestic stone steps of the Butterley spillway are also threatened. Its owner, Yorskhire Water, plans to upgrade the structure with a concrete replacement, as it fails to comply with current health and safety standards. But the Victorian Society argues that the kind of flooding the proposed structure seeks to manage may occur only once in 20,000 years.

"Whether the solution is restoration or finding a new use for a building, it always takes money and often a long time," says Costelloe. "In the meantime it's vital that historic buildings are secured against weather and vandals. We owe it to future generations to ensure such memorable buildings are still around in 100 years. Most people now regret the demolition of the Euston Arch – we don't want to see other important examples of our history lost to neglect, crime or short term economic concerns."

Also on the list is a fine red-brick pumphouse, with turrets and pointed arches, left crumbling on the edge of a container park in Bootle, Merseyside, as well as London's Holborn Circus, described by Dickens as "perhaps … the finest piece of street architecture in the City" – now threatened by a plan to move the central statue and close off one of the roads.

How to write while looking after a very young baby: get a sling. Aim for the most supportive, ergonomic one you can find. Strap yourself in. After the mid-morning feed, while the baby is still in a post-milk trance, insert her into the sling with the minimum disturbance possible. Forget anything like clearing away the breakfast, emptying the washing machine, returning calls – even dressing. You won't be doing anything as rash as answering the door.

Walk to your desk, averting your eyes from the heaps of laundry on the stairs, the drifts of cat hair on the carpets, the flotsam of toys in every doorway. Don't hurry. Don't indicate you have anything in mind other than a relaxing stroll. Use the swaying, rolling gait of an astronaut. Try not to show your excitement or your nerves. You are about to carve some time out of the day – you are about to step out of the chaos – but keep it light. Soothing murmurs at this point are optional but might help.

Slide yourself into your chair and switch on the computer, having previously ensured the volume is turned right down, so the machine doesn't emit a sleep-shattering BONG in welcome. Everyone knows there is no more sombre enemy to good art than the broadband connection in the hallway, so disable your router immediately. Do not check your email, do not click on your favourites, do not check today's headlines, do not be tempted to see how your eBay auctions are faring: go to work, go directly to work.

There is nothing more focusing than the awareness that your beloved infant may wake at any moment, that tiny, known body flexing and arching into consciousness, putting an end to work. The tension – will you get 20 minutes today, or 40, or even an hour? – will help encourage a little adrenaline, or so you tell yourself. You scroll through the paragraphs and find your place from yesterday, helpfully highlighted in block capitals.

If you find yourself fogged by fatigue or blindsided by exhaustion, try a square or two of chocolate – dark and bitter. A glass of water or music can also help. Choose something that will transport you to the mood or time or atmosphere of whatever you are writing. Put it on repeat until you don't hear it any more.

Write. The clickety-clackety of the keyboard will soothe her, and you. Write without looking back, without rereading. Write until your fingers are stiff, your shoulders sore, your eyes aching. Write until you feel her twisting her head from side to side, until you unstrap the sling, lifting her out and into your arms. You might be in the middle of a sentence but no matter. Type "HERE" in capitals and then push yourself away from the desk, carrying her out of the room, shutting the door until next time.

A bigger proportion of UK marketers slashed their ad budgets in the third quarter of 2012 than at any time since the throes of the recession three years ago.

The IPA's influential Bellwether survey, which gauges the outlook of the UK marketing industry, found there is a very real chance the amount spent on marketing will decline year on year in 2012.

This signifies a massive deterioration in confidence since the start of the year when marketers had believed there would be a "mild rise" in spend, fuelled by events such as Euro 2012, the diamond jubilee and the Olympics.

As companies looked to control costs to manage profitability in a tough trading environment, they cut back on their marketing budgets.

More than a third of companies said they were pessimistic about the prospects for the advertising and marketing industry, while about 30% said they felt negative about the future.

"We had hoped when the year started that things were picking up but as time has gone on the economy has stuttered and confidence isn't particularly strong," said the IPA president, Nicola Mendelsohn.

A breakdown of the survey data showed marketers are cutting budgets to all media – from TV and radio to cinema and outdoor advertising – except the internet.

Budgets for internet advertising grew for the 13th quarter in a row.

Police have warned the media to avoid filming or photographing the faces of anyone entering the first ever private abortion clinic on the island of Ireland.

The Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) said any film or pictures identifying clients or staff going into the building in central Belfast would be a breach of the European Convention on Human Rights as well as UK law.

The Marie Stopes clinic on Belfast's Great Victoria Street is scheduled to open on Thursday and is expected to become the focal point of protests by anti-abortion activists across Ireland, north and south.

In advance of the clinic opening its doors, the PSNI issued advice that the media should pixelate the faces of any individual they may record entering the building.

A PSNI spokesman said the request was in line with Article 8 of the ECHR, which has been enshrined in UK law. He said the PSNI had a duty under the legislation "to protect a person's right to privacy from interference by others, in certain circumstances".

Marie Stopes' director for the UK and Ireland, Tracey McNeill, revealed that the sexual health charity had hired security staff to protect its workers and clients.

Anti-abortion activists have said they will stage a mass protest outside the clinic at around lunchtime on Thursday. The founder of the pressure group Precious Life, Bernadette Smyth, said her supporters would observe "three days of prayer and fasting" to demonstrate their opposition to the clinic.

Northern Ireland is the only part of the UK where the 1967 Abortion Act does not apply and has resulted in thousands of women from the province travelling to Britain and Europe for terminations.

In the Irish Republic there is an absolute ban on all abortions and the opening of the abortion services, although limited, creates the prospect of women from the republic being able to legally terminate their pregnancies on the island for the first time.

Britain's laws to tackle wildlife crime – such as the poisoning of birds of prey and illegal trading of species online – are a "mess", an influential committee of MPs said on Thursday.

The report from the environmental audit committee comes amid fears over the funding of the police's National Wildlife Crime Unit (NWCU), which is due to expire in March next year and has not yet been guaranteed by the government.

While laws to protect wildlife in the UK exist, the committee acknowledges, their power is undermined as they are "scattered across various statutes and regulations". The Association of Chief Police Officers (Acpo) told the committee "conservation legislation is, in our view, badly in need of consolidation".

Several laws, such as the Night Poaching Act of 1828 and the Game Act of 1831, are archaic, for example, while the main legislation under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 is difficult for non-wildlife specialist lawyers to use. The Law Commission is currently consulting on wildlife laws, which it calls "a legal landscape that is out of date, confused and often contradictory."

Prosecution of cases, such as the poisoning of peregrine falcons, is also hampered by a lack of knowledge in the Crown Prosecution Service and "inconsistent sentencing by judges and magistrates", the report says. "We have an issue with continuity with the CPS because there aren't specialist prosecutors for wildlife," Stephanie Pendry, enforcement programme leader at the wildlife trade monitoring NGO Traffic, told the committee.

If successfully prosecuted, most wildlife crimes in the UK incur a maximum £5,000 fine and/or a maximum sentence of six months.

Joan Walley, the committee's chair, said: "Police officers dealing with wildlife crime are having to wrestle with legal arrangements that are almost Pythonesque in their absurdity; like the requirement to summon a vet to take a sample from any endangered species entering the country – even if it happens to be a piece of mahogany furniture.

"Wildlife protection law in the UK is in a mess after being patched up too many times in an effort to keep pace with offending. The law needs to be consolidated and the courts need to be given clear sentencing guidelines."

Uncertainty over the long-term funding of the NWCU is also undermining its ability to carry out enforcement, the committee heard, as it is constantly under review. Nevin Hunter, the head of the unit, said: "… A lot of the challenge that I have is to constantly look at securing the future funding, which takes me away from that day-to-day role of trying to address wildlife crime."

The unit is relatively small, with a staff of just 15, and its £397,000 funding largely split between the Home Office and the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra). Its funding for 2012-13 has already been cut 10% against 2011-12.

Heather Sohl, senior species policy officer for WWF-UK said: "Today, the committee has rightly acknowledged that the UK has made good progress in the last eight years, but to build on success we need the government to recognise that the NWCU needs long-term funding to help stop wildlife crime."

Lord Henley, the then parliamentary under-secretary of state at the Defra, said in August that he could not "make any positive guarantee" over the unit's funding, and even if a decision was taken to cease funding, "other funds [are] going into policing and dealing with these matters".

Martin Harper, the RSPB's conservation director, said in 2011 there were 100 reports of poisoning incidents of birds of prey, highlighting the need for action: "We are delighted that the environmental audit committee shares our concerns about wildlife crime – particularly those affecting birds of prey. We urge the government to heed this advice and we trust it will now take the lead on consigning these acts to history. The committee has clearly signalled that the game is up for wildlife criminals and it's time for a step change in wildlife crime enforcement."

A Defra spokeswoman said: "The government takes the issue of wildlife crime seriously. That is why we fund the National Wildlife Crime Unit, who work to bring these criminals to justice. We will consider the committee's recommendations carefully and will respond in December."

In a statement, the Environmental Investigation Agency, said it welcomed the report and was: "strongly supportive of the committee's call on the government to urgently address failings in current UK wildlife protection legislation. In terms of international wildlife crime, EIA is glad to see the committee urging the UK government to exert 'robust diplomatic pressure' in seeking the development and enforcement of wildlife law at the next Cites meeting in March 2013."

So you're in a rain delay

Kim emails an excellent question here:

Can you give us a run down on how/when it’s decided to “call” a game due to weather?

It's kind of more of an art than a science, if that makes any sense. I'm going to go the lazy student route here and copy and paste from Wikipedia:

Umpires are required by rule to wait at least 30 minutes to see if conditions improve; this is referred to as a rain delay and is not counted as part of the length of the game listed in the box score. In practice, umpires are encouraged to see that games are played if at all possible, and will sometimes wait as long as three hours before declaring a rainout.

Now, here's the thing about the postseason. In the regular season, if this game were called, the Cardinals would have won as they have the lead and it's an official game (meaning it's gone five full innings). However, in the postseason, any games called during a rain delay have to be played to completion. So, say they call this game in a few hours because it's just not going to be playable. That means they restart this game, say tomorrow, in the same situation that it is now: Runners on second and third, two out, bottom of the seventh. Obviously the personnel would be different.

Does this make any sense? Essentially teams have to play at least nine inning games to win postseason games, no matter what the conditions.

Yes, guess who's (weather permitting) covering another Kyle Lohse start for the Cardinals? It only makes sense that I would be covering his Game 3 NLCS start, having become something of his Boswell considering that this is Lohse's most important start of the year. The Cardinals are returning home to Busch Stadium to face the San Francisco Giants in a National League Championship Series tied up 1-1. Game 3 could potentially be the turning point of the series, especially since the Giants looking to regain home field advantage with a win on the road.

The Giants are also extra-motivated after the events of their NLCS Game 2 win. Cardinals outfielder Matt Holliday took out Giants shortstop Marco Scutaro when making a hard slide trying to break up a double play. Scutaro stayed in the game, but his status for this afternoon's game is in doubt. Now, Scutaro immediate revenge on the field as he got a crucial hit that drove in three key runs that helped seal the Cardinals 7-1 victory, but there's the very real possibility that this could be a very chippy game. If hitters on either side start getting plunked, whether it's accidental or on purpose, watch out for some potential fireworks. We are on official bench-clearing watch, people, this is not a drill.

On the mound for the Giants? That would be their ace Matt Cain, who kept the team in the playoff mix while former stopper Tim Lincecum struggled. The underrated hurler achieved some additional renown this year when he threw a perfect game on June 13th against the Houston Astros. He'll be on hand to try to prevent the Cardinals from continuing yet another improbable playoff run. This would fulfill the desires of countless baseball fans who are beginning to see the Cardinals as the National League version of the New York Yankees (who, in case you were wondering, fell to the 0-3 in the American League Championship Series last night after losing to the Detroit Tigers 2-1).

Of course, there's a question about if the game is actually going to start. The weather report around game time says there's about an 80% chance of rain. There's been discussion off and on today about delaying the game or postponing it altogether. We'll see how this goes. Fingers-crossed we'll have baseball sooner rather than later. After all, if the Yankees are eliminated tonight, that means no more double-headers this year, and that would just be sad.

Britain's emergency services are being trained to tackle a marauding terrorist gun attack in the aftermath of the recent attacks in Toulouse and Norway, the security minister, James Brokenshire, is to disclose on Thursday.

In a speech to the Royal United Services Institute in London, the security minister says that the home secretary has ordered a new programme of work to improve the way the emergency services respond to the changing tactics of terrorists.

He says that the experiences in Toulouse, where three children and a rabbi were murdered in an shooting attack on a Jewish school in March, and the Oslo bombings and Utøya shootings in which 77 people died last year demonstrated the impact that a lone individual can have if sufficiently motivated.

"The overall aim is to ensure that the blue light services are trained and exercised to work together as effectively as possible in response to fast-moving terrorist scenarios, so that as many lives as possible can be saved," he says.

"The programme will build upon the work done to date on the joint emergency response to specific risks, including a marauding terrorist firearms attack and incidents involving chemical, biological, radiological or nuclear substances. Staying ahead of the threat means ensuring our emergency response is capable of dealing with the threat in whatever form it takes," says Brokenshire.

The Home Office minister is also to reflect security service concerns about northern Mali joining the list of places that lack any effective government such as Somalia, Afghanistan and Yemen and where terrorism now flourishes.

He said that since a coup earlier this year, some Tuareg groups have forged closer alliances with al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb, and a "collective failure to act" over northern Mali "might well become manifest in attacks closer to home," warns Brokenshire.

The security minister confirms that the Home Office will implement a "no-fly list" under which airlines will be denied authority to carry foreign nationals who pose a terrorist threat on flights to Britain.

He is also to defend the government's plans to track email and mobile phone use in the communications data bill arguing that terrorists are using internet messaging, phone services and even video games to communicate. The security minister says that the delivery of a safe and secure Olympic Games does not mean that the threat from al-Qaida has disappeared.

"Those who want to do us serious harm are waiting for the moment we take our eye off the ball. The number of terrorism arrests rose from 126 in 2010/11 to 206 in 2011/12. Two hundred and eighty three persons have been convicted of a terrorism-related offence since 11 September 2000. The threat remains very real," says Brokenshire.
